review:
I want to preface this with a caveat: This is a [b]hesitant recommendation[/b].

When this originally came out on Kongregate years ago, the internet was in a different place. Certain puzzles [i]can no longer be solved[/i] via their intended means, such as a Twitter bot or a newspaper article. However, in both cases the Steam forums or guides will be your friend. Don't be afraid to look something up; the game already expects you to solve some puzzles via searching the internet.

With that out of the way, let me say that this is a really clever game with a neat premise. Perhaps a little [i]too[/i] clever for its own good, but more on that later. The mechanic of looking through a computer's files (in-game) to obtain background information, clues, and solutions [i]does[/i] follow through with the notion that you're "becoming a hacker". Of course, this is nothing like Uplink or games which feature huge networks or faux social settings.

It is simply going going from computer to computer on the Mu Complex network to figure out what's going on and possibly uncover some secrets. There [i]are not[/i] "hundreds of emails" to read. At a rough guess I'd say there's like 40. This is not a large game, though Episode 2 is longer and more difficult than the first. I spent maybe an hour and a half on the first one, and upwards of 5 hours on the second cause I ran into several puzzles I couldn't initially wrap my brain around.

That leads to one of my biggest criticisms: the hints are both terribly vague and take upwards of 16 minutes to unlock depending on the puzzle/computer. When all you wanted was a better understanding of how, say, the bot puzzles worked in Episode 2 and nothing was leaping out.. that's when I was forced to go watch a gameplay walkthrough to see the commands in action.

My completely failing to notice the bot is initially positioned [i]downwards[/i] did not help, but that is completely on. :D

By and large I think the game is just fine and enjoyed most of my time with it. [b]It's a shame there will never be an Episode 3[/b] that it was so heavily pushing towards, because not nearly enough people could finish the game (in the developers own words) to warrant their time and money making it. That's why I said I felt the game was trying too hard to be clever; it shot itself in the foot.

[i]It's not a bad game,[/i] but it has run afoul of the passage of time and some puzzles simply being too obtuse for their own good. I still have no clue how you're expected to discover the password for Olivier Riddle's computer, for instance.

The other, and this is a big one, shortcoming is that the game is [i]prone to crashing.[/i] Often doing so during cinematics such as the game's opening logos or the end of Episode 1. Sometimes it will simply crash when I've tabbed out for a few minutes. When it does so, [i]I have to revalidate the files[/i] for whatever reason. But it works and I can move on. 

Please consider waiting for a sale if you wish to try it. Just be aware of these things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041603555', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1645259122}
review:
Mu Complex is a "hacker adventure" where your poking onto random terminals have opened up a world of discovery, opportunity, and... a bit of WTF had happened. Some of the puzzles require going into the real world for clues, but it wasn't clear when that was totally necessary, and often, totally anachronistic. And at the end, it relied on a timed puzzle that basically forced me to rage quit. 

Some of the puzzles are relatively clever, the former inhabitants left clues that are not visible in regular light, but are visible under blacklight or thermal or IR, as you hack one computer after another, discovering more clues along the way. 

But the game went seriously anachronistic when it was supposedly set in the 1960's, but it has a password reset procedure that tells you to access a mail server through URL. Keep in mind that http wasn't invented until 1989 by Tim Berners-Lee and team. Another clue later requires clues from a token posted by a Twitter account, which isn't active until 2006! (And the token Twitter account was created 2015!) Yet ANOTHER clue requires research of a real newspaper on Google for a specific page on a specific date in the 1960's. 

Some of the puzzles are clever, but the final few puzzles rely on time limits. Do two serious multiplication and addition based on a random number in 30 seconds. There's just not enough time unless you're lightning fast on the calculator AND the keyboard. 

And the plot? Hah, derivative. Let's just say the name LYA is very reminiscent of another AI, shall we? 

Well, enough said.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004104607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1637982804}
review:
I've had this game on my wish list for 6 years, waiting for it to go on sale. I have a soft spot for ARGs and these kinds of "hacking" puzzle games, but I'm usually disappointed with the genre. The "hacking" usually boils down to obscuring the game's mechanics behind a severely dumbed down, limited and frustrating command line interface, then forcing you to solve what boils down to sudoku puzzles and anagrams as the meat of the game. I've been a software engineer since the 90s, I'm basically setting myself up for disappointment whenever I play one of these.

This game ended up being pretty much like every other hacking simulator I've played. The first episode was entertaining, although a bit simple. It would have been the perfect length and difficulty for a demo. I was pleasantly surprised when I dropped into a command line and was able to instinctively use "ls" and "cat" to show the contents of a directory and dump a file to the terminal to read it, without having to view the available commands. Oh, and occasionally a file requires root privs to view, so you have to use "sudo" once in a while. Well, that's pretty much where the realism of the shell environment ends. Not to mention the system you're using was supposed to have been built in the early 1960s, well before Unix even existed.

You can "cat" jpgs to view them. ssh works without user names and passwords are stored in text files. You spend the majority of your time interfacing with the terminal, but can't customize the font size, scroll with your mouse wheel or copy/paste. It would have been nice if some of the challenge came from realistically having to socially engineer information, or having to use some kind of packet sniffer or port scanner to illicitly gain knowledge. But instead you basically solve slider puzzles and anagrams, with the terminal and network acting as minor roadblocks to finding all the pieces of the puzzle so you can rearrange them into an answer.

There's one puzzle that requires you to look up a real back issue of a newspaper, which at the time this was released was probably freely available but which is now hidden behind a paywall. You'll now either have to subscribe to the newspaper to view this solution or you'll have to use the Chrome inspector to delete elements from the page to get past the paywall and view a blurry rendition of the image you need. That's the closest thing to "hacking" I did when playing this game, and it's just a matter of time before that probably won't work either.

I got bored about halfway through the second chapter. I could have continued jumping around the serially networked computers to solve the silly ciphers, but I just didn't want to any more.

As far as this kind of "hacking" simulator, still to this day there is no better game than Telehack. It's 100% free and 1000% more realistic, deep and rewarding than anything else I've tried in this genre in the last 10 years. TIS-100 is a close second, if you like solving brain teasers dressed in retro computer wrappings. 

As far as Mu Complex, well, I can't say I recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961643982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1631919361}
review:
[i]MU complex[/i] is a short, but well-executed, fun, and challenging terminal based hacking game. It's straight-forward in the sense that you work your way through a network of computers, gathering files and tools using command lines. It's also out-of-the-box in the sense that, contrasting hacking games like [i]Hacknet[/i] or the superb [i]Nite Team 4[/i], this game focuses a lot on riddles and puzzles, which often require you to use external sources. After an evening of playing this game, you'll be left with a long list of written notes and at least a dozen of opened browser tabs.

I highly recommend this game to lovers of the puzzle-slash-hacking genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969157720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1625614903}
review:
While the game is actually quite interesting and puzzles are actually fun to do, I just cant recommend it due to one reason, the lack of developer awareness to outside resources this game requests. One puzzle has you looking for something on google, and while that sounds great(and in theory is) you can only get the information off a paid website, which forces you to pretty much look at a guide for answers or some obscure hints given by the community to circumvent this issue. This wasnt the case on release but the website went paid after some time and now is stuck behind that paywall. The community has brought this up and the devs are pretty much ignored it as well as trying to counter the argument. This left a bad taste in my mouth as the game is really short as is. 

I wouldn't mind this problem and could look past this one puzzle if the game was quite long, but you can beat the game in less than 2 hours, so having to use a guide for an answer because the answer is pretty much paywalled now and they don't want to do anything about it, is just garbage.

It's a shame, after that one google puzzle the other google style puzzles were way too basic and not very well thought out, essentially boiling down to "search what this word means and type the result". The stuff contained within the game though, such as hacking the computers and going through the levels was actually pretty fun.

There was another puzzle or 2 that required some knowledge of programs outside of the game which was quite annoying to try to figure out, as I knew how to solve the puzzle, but figuring out how to do it required me to basically look up a tutorial on google on how to do something special with a program in my computer(or the requirement to download one if you dont have that function on your pc). 

Also, they also said that chapter 3 would release but due to not enough support, they left it at 2 chapters. Eh.

review:
Clunky, slow and not very logical for a puzzle game.
---

You start out needing to log in to a computer terminal, what kind of system lets you just ask for the log in password and let you log in with it?

You log in and "finding the password" was treated as a test? It literally only required typing the word password to find it. And the game tells you that it was surprised you could accomplish this; really? 

It doesn't really get any better after this. The interface is tiny and can't be adjusted, in fact there's no options for display at all so if you have a large screen you are locked into tiny text and a poor UI design.

The story continues on through more nonsense puzzles like the first one, open a file, find the word you need to enter for the next puzzle, continue. It's mediocre once, and it's tedious if this is the main interaction with the game repeatedly. It's about as fun as using windows explorer to investigate what's taking up space on your hard drive and cleaning out old temp files.

There's so many flaws in the way this is written and the way you interact with it, you sit at a computer terminal but can't even scroll up the window (which has a scroll bar) because it's just a visual gimmick, nah you get to resend commands over again to relist things in the tiny context window.

And even more strange is the game requires you to look up information outside of the game (in another web browser) in order to make progress, but the games not stable enough to stay open all the time when you do. I hit a few puzzles that you needed to go do out-of-game research to pass and the game would crash frequently when it wasn't the focused window. For such a simple game you would think it would be stable, but no.

Game length will also be completely subjective. The actual content (reading material and audio narration) is far less than an hour long. Any length of play-time you get from the game will be browsing for answers (in or out of game) to find the password to the next snippet of narration.

Overall this is a neat idea and I actually do think there might be some people who will enjoy it, but it's going to be a very niche audience and I'm not going to recommend it for most people. It's just not well presented, it's missing basic functional tools and it's insultingly glitchy on top of that.

If you are mildly curious about the story, go look up a speed run for each episode and you'll get to see the entire 10 minutes of game content and the slightly interesting (and easily predictable) ending.
[spoiler]Gee, what always happens when you "free" an AI?[/spoiler]

EDIT: I guess I should point out there's a demo just in case you didn't notice, so if you really wanted to see if this is for you, you can try it for free.
---

Bottom line: The steam backgrounds for this game are better than the game, and less prone to crashing.

review:
Ожидал интересную головоломку, в итоге получил...что-то несколько другое.

Эта игра могла бы быть интересной, но у неё есть одна серьёзная проблема, которая бьёт по многим местам и лишает всякого удовольствия.
Проблема, о которой я говорю, - необходимость пользоваться внешними (внеигровыми ресурсами) для прохождения. К тому же в игре никогда прямо не говорится, что тебе нужно искать что-то ВНЕ игры.

К чему это приводит:
- портится атмосфера от прохождения, т.к. тебе нередко приходится скакать между окнами
- нельзя быть полностью уверенным что ты делаешь всё правильно (как предусмотрел разработчик)
- повышается вероятность увидеть больше, чем планировал (непреднамеренный просмотр гайдов)
- большая привязка к работоспособности сайтов/интернета (один из паззлов уже нельзя выполнить как предусматривал разработчик из-за того, что один конкретный сайт стал платным, т.е. самостоятельно уже не пройдёшь)
- лично у меня игра иногда зависала при смене окон и приходилось её перезапускать несколько раз

Сюжет здесь минимален и что-то проявляется только под конец игры.
Интерфейс немного пустоват (во время прохождения), из-за чего кажется, что чего-то не хватает.

Я НЕ советую покупать эту игру, если вы просто рассчитываете на лёгкую идеальную игру. Некоторые достижения получить проблематично (как я понимаю, не повезло обладателям Windows 10).

Если вас просто заинтересовала игра - пробуйте на свой страх и риск. Я разочаровался. Возможно, вам она понравится больше.

review:
[b]Too Long; Don't Wanna Read:[/b] fun puzzle solving game, alright music, story is zzzzzz, good afternoon waster

So first off, I've been following this game since episode 1 was on Kongregate. I beat it way back and really enjoyed it, excited for episode 2. After a while, I found that it got removed from Kong and got quite upset, but soon after I found it on steam and wishlisted it. I bought it on sale after a year or so, and kept going on and off on the game multiple times until I finally sat down and finished the game start to finish today. I say this because I wanted to say that this history I've had with it has allowed me to view and enjoy this game at multiple points in time and different perspectives, and the one thing that has been very consistent over time is that the game is fun. Going through the different computers and finding the passwords through puzzle solving in multiple ways was quite fun. I especially liked the part where you'd have to use online tools such as googling a certain verse to get the information needed. The music was one thing I started to appreciate as I got older, it's nice ambient music in the bg that quite fits the tech startup company graphics, which I also liked. It's alright, but nothing to write home about (although I wish I was able to find the OST online somewhere....). The story, however, was the part that I least cared about. It wasn't *bad*, but it was really basic, cliche, and I honestly couldn't care about it. It didn't affect the game much but if you were going into this game for its story then this might not be your thing. If, however, you are looking for a hacker/command line game where you jump between computer to computer, using ciphers and hints between computers to progress, pick this game up! I would say if you're not super pressed, wait for a sale or smth, I personally enjoyed it back when it was a flash game on Kongregate and honestly, I feel this game definitely deserved more than free flash game status.

review:
Das Spiel hat weniger was mit Hacken/Programmieren zu tun, es ist eher eine moderne Cyber-Schatzsuche. Zwar muss man mit kurzen Befehlen das Termial steuern, aber alles wird in der Hilfe angezeigt und ist simpel zu lösen. Das eigentliche Spiel geht um das Lösen der Rätsel auf ECHTEN Internetseiten und macht viel Spaß. Es sind nichtmal DOS oder Linux Kenntnisse notwendig, aber ihr solltet ein Grundverständnis von Informationstechnologie mitbringen. Alles ist recht gut zu lesen, auch wenn es nur auf Englisch ist, aber das war kein Problem. Spiel wird ohne Maus gespielt. Fenstermodus macht Sinn, denn ihr seid mehr auf eurem echten PC unterwegs als im Spiel. Wiederspielbarkeit ist bedingt gegeben, weil manche Zahlenrätsel live berechnet werden, aber bei den meisten ist die Lösungen fest verankert. Mathe und logisches Denken wird auch abgefragt. Von mir klare Kaufempfehlung, auch wenn es immerhin 9€ kostet und man wohl nur so 5 oder 6 Stunden damit beschäftigt sein dürfte. 

Wer neugierig ist, was man alles zum Beispiel im Netz erforschen muss, hier kleiner Spoiler:
[spoiler]
- in Online-Archiven von Zeitungen blättern (verbuggt)
- in der Bibel lesen
- Fotos anfertigen und bearbeiten (Photoshop-Ebenen)
- Morse-Codes entziffern
- Internet-Rechner zum Dechiffrieren nutzen
- Passwörter auf echten Twitter Profilen suchen
- versteckte Hinweise in Filmportalen finden
- eigene Karten auf G.Maps erstellen!!! 
[/spoiler]
Es kommt nicht an Uplink oder hacknet als Hackerspiel ran, aber wer Lust auf Schnitzeljagd hat, ist hier richtig!

author: {'steamid': '76561198139842245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1562127671}
review:
As one of the OG fans of this game on Kongregate back when episode 1 just came out, I have to say, I am so happy this game got an overhaul and came to steam. This has got to be one of my favourite puzzle games of all time for two reasons.

One, the theme. It's hard to find good hacking puzzle games nowadays, and while I don't quite believe MU beats hacknet (yet anyway) it's definitely second on the list of them. The game doesn't rely on too much hacking knowledge, but it's just enough to reward those with it a little.

Two, the difficulty. A lot of these type of puzzle games are either far too difficult, or much too easy. MU, in my opinion, falls almost perfectly into the space between the two. It's not afraid to punch you with a challenge, but at the same time it feels set up so the answer isn't found farther than the top of google search results. That, and if it makes you do something difficult, it doesn't stack another challenge on top of that, it just ends. This way you either get something that is very difficult but that's it and you progress, or you have to piece together a few easier challenges to get past. This really encourages you to give it your all when working on a puzzle, and to not type hint unless your face is right up against the wall.

TL;DR If you like hacking games that aren't afraid to be difficult and are great at balancing challenge and reward, look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045453835', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1471069929}
review:
So, I generally love hacking games. I even loved this game when it first came out.

But I can't recommend it.

Pros:
-Interesting story
-Well made puzzles (Sort of)
-ARG puzzles that make you think

Cons:
-Not really a hacking simulator. The "hacking" is more of a basis for brain teasers. If you want something far closer to a hacking simulator, I highly recommend either Uplink, Hacknet, or Nite Team 4. Those games, while still puzzles, are FAR closer to the reality of hacking than this is.
-While the puzzles are well made, there's a major caveat to that. Some of the ARG puzzle solutions are no longer accessible. That's one of the dangers of making an ARG based puzzle game and not frequently updating it. This game came out several years ago, and the more heavily reliant you are on ARG based puzzles, the more likely the game will be unplayable without a walkthrough down the line. If you're interested in ARG puzzles, look into The Black Watchmen or any of the games made by Alice & Smith (its developer).

My Major Gripe:
If you look at the game's history, you'll find that the game itself has actually existed for a long time. It was originally released in multiple parts on Kongregate around 2014 as a free web browser game. About a year later, it was successfully greenlit and launched onto Steam. It was then immediately removed from Kongregate. What you are playing here was originally released for free. Now, while that's a scummy thing to do, maybe they were just hoping to push forward with further development, right?

Well, the team launched their website back in late 2014 with an ARG event which required people to unlock the website before it could be viewed. It was, of course, unlocked. The next announced news on the website was in late 2015 with the release of the Steam version. That's the last time they released anything on their website. The last update to the game was in early 2016 with the release of a demo for the game.

They've been radio silent since. Which is a damn shame because after alienating their audience by removing the Kongregate version and throwing a huge stinger into the game's ending for what has to be what they planned for a sequel...there's been nothing for *years*. So the lack of updates to the ARG aren't the only aspect of the game that's been abandoned. It appears the whole project has.

Summary:
If this game is on a huge sale and you REALLY want to play it, go ahead and buy it. If you're interested in ARG puzzle games, there's far better options to select from on Steam (Alice & Smith Games would come highly recommended by me). If you want to play a hacking game, there's a ton of options you can select from that more accurately give you the feel of hacking (Hacknet, Uplink, Nite Team 4). If you appreciate what the developers have made here and want to see more from them, be aware that they've taken some scummy actions towards their community and have been totally radio silent for three years now.

Executive Summary:
Get it on sale if at all. Look into other games if you like the genera.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035273850', 'num_games_owned': 1375, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1546644427}
review:
[b]Très vite[/b], si on voit les intentions du développeur, c’est trop mal exécuté, et surtout trop mal écrit pour mériter qu’on s’y attarde.

[b]Plus rentrer dans les détails[/b], on sent que l’inspiration fondamentale des développeurs (un studio de 3 personnes) est à chercher d’un côté dans le [i]hacking[/i], et de l'autre dans les jeux s’appuyant sur des éléments en dehors du support, par exemple des livres, mais plus généralement des sites web. On pensera notamment à des jeux comme [b]In Memoriam[/b]. Ça, ce sont les intentions, et elles sont louables. Souci, l’exécution n’est pas vraiment au niveau.

La partie hacking se veut « réaliste », en reprenant un terminal avec une poignée de commandes inspirées d’Unix. Sauf que c’est plus simplement de l’administration et pas du « hacking » au sens du contournement de systèmes. Tout est trop éloigné de la réalité pour qu’une personne qui connaisse vraiment Unix y retrouve ses habitudes. Sans compter que l’aspect sécurité tient du ridicule : alors que l’histoire est censée se dérouler dans un centre de très haute sécurité, on trouve des mots de passe en clair un peu de partout, et on peut littéralement sauter d’une machine à l’autre par ssh sans autre forme de procès. C’est littéralement n’importe quoi.

Second axe, les puzzles qu’il faut résoudre en cherchant des éléments sur le web. C’est suffisamment rare pour louer l’initiative, mais le problème est la pérennité des sources. Si les sites et le compte Twitter mis en place sont toujours opérationnels un peu plus de 3 ans après la sortie du jeu, ce n’est par contre pas le cas des ressources externes. Le cas le plus flagrant est quand nous est demandé de trouver une publicité particulière située dans telle page de tel numéro d’un journal américain régional. Sauf qu’entre temps, les archives qui étaient librement accessibles lors de la sortie du jeu sont maintenant payantes. La manière la plus simple pour s’en sortir est encore de suivre [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=610983814]un guide[/url].

Guide qu’il sera préférable de garder à portée de main car entre les énigmes mal expliquées, et celles qui sont simplement fastidieuses, l’envie de réfléchir est remplacée par celle d’en finir le plus vite possible. Car certains des puzzles orientés « hacking » (en vrai, autant orientés hacking qu’un jeu de cubes est comparable à un chantier de construction) demandent de réaliser des opérations en temps très limité, ou pour d’autre de suivre des restrictions totalement artificielles.

Artificiel est d’ailleurs le maître-mot de la critique de [b]Mu Complex[/b], tant rien ne semble cohérent, tout semble construit pour faire énigme de jeu vidéo. L’écriture est d’ailleurs assez symptomatique : les personnages, n’existant qu’au travers de courriels, ont assez peu d’épaisseur, et la trame globale est cousue de fil blanc. Clichée au possible, elle ne surprend que par son premier degré et sa bêtise.

Si on peut comprendre les intentions des développeurs, et leur volonté de « faire vrai », on ne peut que constater la maladresse de mise en place, et recommander d’éviter ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024542280', 'num_games_owned': 735, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1531547215}
review:
I sure am glad that I completed the game in under two hours, because after writing this review, I am going to refund it.

There are minor spoilers below. I mainly talk about the nature of some puzzles, without providing actualy solutions.

Despite the claims on the store page, this isn't much of a hacking game. Sure, there's a terminal window that you type commands into, but in general, this is more of a test of your google-fu skills than anything. Even that isn't particularily hard, since half of the computers are "hacked" by skimming through some emails, figuring out what whacky "encoding" is used for that particular password, and looking up an online converter.

The other half involves some rather odd puzzles. On a couple of occasions you are required to navigate a robot through a "maze" consisting of a single corridor with no alternative routes. This is done by typing in commands in the console using a somewhat inconsistent metasyntax, and having the robot execute them in order. Actually, there are inconsistencies all over Mu Complex. There are two puzzles that look virtually identical. The first one is solved with some quick math, the other one isn't.

Oh, and there is one puzzle that requires you to sign up for a free trial for a newspaper archive, which in turn requires you to provide your credit card details. If you don't have a credit card, or have already used up the trial period in the past, you are pretty much screwed. The only option here is to look up a walkthrough that straight up tells you the password. Good luck with that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977520619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1530742671}
review:
The one thing that's necessary for a hacking sim to work is for the rules to be consistent.
On some computers, you'll need to "sudo" to open email files. (In real life, this isn't usually necessary, but doesn't hurt unless it contains a virus.)
On other computers, if you preemptively type "sudo" just in case, it will reject the command because that computer doesn't know "sudo".
Sometimes, files appear out of nowhere on allegedly abandoned computers after certain events, requiring you to double check all your steps to avoid missing anything, even when locking them until that point COULD have been incorporated into the existing game mechanics. 
Some puzzles require copying text into certain external translators. As the game window doesn't allow highlighting text, the user has to manually type the entire sequence.
The bot-control puzzle's instructions use inconsistent metasyntax, appearing as if multple commands can be pushed with a single line. That entire puzzle takes way too many steps for how simple it is to understand anyway.
There's also a puzzle which requires checking the real Chicago Tribune archives on the internet, which is now behind a paywall.
A general lack of foresight and attention to detail make an otherwise average hacking sim feel clunky and shallow at best and outright offensive at worst.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035448621', 'num_games_owned': 703, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1529590849}
review:
Un bon titre dans le genre de niche des jeux en console de commande ! 

Pas vraiment du hacking à proprement parler, mais plutôt une successions d'énigmes à résoudre pour pouvoir pénétrer toujours plus loin dans le système informatique du complexe; et pour ce faire on utilise des commandes resemblant un peu à celles de linux, ce qui donne ce feeling particulier recherché des fans du genre. 

Les énigmes sont variées et demandent souvent de la recherche sur internet. Elles s'inscrivent bien dans l'histoire bien foutue qu'on découvre peu à peu au travers des mails et des fichiers laissés par les protagonistes. Certaines ne sont pas évidentes, mais en général ça reste d'un niveau correct.

On a même droit à une cinématique à la fin ! Ha le luxe ! ;-) En tous cas la cinématique principale, car il y a bien sûr quelques secrets dans ce jeu, et grand coup de chapeau à ceux qui trouveront la fin alternative sans aucune aide...

On aimerait un troisième épisode, mais ça n'a pas l'air gagné... 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198085798542', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2680, 'last_played': 1500129188}
review:
L'histoire de ce jeu est simple à terminer, mais si vous vous sentez hacker dans l'âme, alors ce sera une autre paire de manches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002263172', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1501862998}
review:
Interesting idea, but I am sad to say that the execution is lacking. There are some serious quality of life improvements required to make this less frustrating for regular terminal users.

The game (and terminal) doesn't properly resize to fit the resolution (2560x1600), so you are stuck with a lot of scrolling to read stuff that would have comfortably fit on the monitor otherwise. The mouse wheel doesn't work and the scroll handle is tiny and therefore very fiddly. There doesn't even seem to be any keyboard shortcuts for scrolling, which would have been fine, too.

I got through Episode 1 easily enough, but stopped playing during some puzzles in Episode 2 that require typing a lot of rather wordy commands in a very specific order. Failing one of these apparently requires re-typing all of it. The solution was easy, but extremely tedious to enter. This, combined with the lack of context (due to the small window and lack of halfway decent scrolling) made it frustrating enough for me to just quit right there.

My experience with the puzzles is limited by the fact that I stopped playing, but most puzzles so far seem to consist out of rather repetitively digging through emails, finding a clue and entering the result. Sometimes it also requires you to Google for some piece of text that the clue references to find the answer. Also, this is nowhere near a "full-featured hacker" experience. There is only a handful of limited commands, and you could probably just brute-force your way through all of it.

I would have liked to know how the story ends, but in its current state, I am not willing to put more time into it to find out.

review:
Mu Complex is a hacking game with rich atmosphere and mindboggling puzzles that require you to think very litteraly outside of the box. This game might even take you along for an even more exciting ARG experience if you wish to uncover every single secret. And believe me, there are quite a few of them.

I played this game way back when Mu Complex Episode 1 launched at Kongregate, and I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of it. Of course I delved straight into Episode 2 when it launched as well. If you pay attention to everything in the game you come across a lot of referances, I'll post some of them under a spoiler tag for those interested. [spoiler] Of course we have the obvious ones like Portal, but you'll also find referances to different parts of history, tools for making and breaking codes (ranging from ASCII to Braille to Navy Flags), and even The Bible [/spoiler] So I believe there is something for most people to enjoy here. You might even learn something new, I sure did.

What's even more exciting is that the Steam version of Mu Complex includes a few new features, so I encourage every fan and those interested in the game to try to collect all the achievements. You'll find that there is more happening between the lines and out of plain sight than you first thought.

Final thoughts: I'm really glad I played through it all and discovered everything. It gives me reason to hope even more for a Mu Complex Episode 3 someday.

Rating: 10/10 A true gem amongst games.

review:
Mu Complex is neat little hacking / puzzle game. The puzzles within are challenging, but not overly impossible. To complete them you sometimes have to think outside the box, and use resources and applications found on your computer. I felt they were constructed in such a way that you could actually learn something by working them, instead of running to a walkthrough or guide.  

I really liked this game, and enjoyed playing it. The only thing negative comment I could think to write about, is that the game’s playtime / story is a little on the short side. If not for the fact that I left the game running, while taking a break, for about 3 hours - my play time would be considerably less. Hopefully the developers will add more episodes and content at some point in the future, that would beg another play through. Overall though, I feel the current game is worth its value and begs to be given a chance. I definitely recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993862065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1185, 'last_played': 1485522224}
review:
Quasi-hacking game that leans on the 4th wall, requires online searching to solve puzzles

Graphics are minimal. most of the interaction is with a Linux-like terminal. There are no sound puzzles. any spoken text is shown on the screen. Some instances have items that are very low contrast, so you may need to adjust your monitor's brightness. That being said, the screen seems locked on 1920x1080 resolution, so if you have a QHD monitor the text will look *tiny*. I used the Windows magnifier to deal with this, although it seemed to make some of the videos crash as they were being played.

Calling this a "hacking" game is a stretch. There are maybe 5 Linux commands that you use in the entire game. Without giving away anything, you'll be using 'cat' and 'ls' alot. There is one place that you absolutely need to understand the Linux commands that you are given to you in order to solve a  timed puzzle. But most of the time you are either solving puzzles by snooping for clues to passwords in the computer system or opening up a search engine outside the game and Google-ing for clues.

Overall, I enjoyed playing it. Much of the time playing was looking up things online. Maybe there's 4-5 hours of gameplay here. I got it on discount so I had a good value for my money, but I wished the game were longer.

review:
I don't really know how I feel about this game.  I have been waiting for a while for it to go on sale and jumped on it this Xmas Sale cycle.  

In summary, the game advertises itself as a "hacking" game with a linux CLI.   This is a far stretch as the Linux commands are extremely limited and only certain ones are available on specific machines.   

The base game was not very diffcult; I finished both Episode 1 and 2 in just over 2 hours.   I actually spent most of my time just trying to get all of the achievement badges, which the 4 hidden ones were actually the most interesting of all of the puzzles.   

Not sure that this game has any replayability value.   Aside from getting the achievements, the puzzles don't change per run through.

All in all,  I want to really like this game... and for buck it did entertain me for a few hours.   But once I have finished writing this review, I will uninstall it from my computer and not play it again.   That statement alone makes it hard for me to recommend to anyone for any price.

review:
Mu Complex is a game about hacking into an old research complex, going through people's files, and trying to help a mysterious AI called Lya. You do this by typing various available commands from a list to open files, unlock computers and make your way to even more computers to do the same.

So, the consensus on this game seems to be that if you are a program/or a fan of Linux, you will be disappointed. However, I as a non-programmer, loved this code-lite "hacking" game. It's far from real hacking, obvious to even one who is not a hacker, because all these bozos keep their passwords on their computers in text files or hid with ciphers and codes that they reveal to others in emails. You are also required to use google for various other puzzles, like looking up ciphers or codes or gps coordinates. The list of available commands is small but not consistent, so that when the "camera" function shows up on a computer, for instance, you know that you must have to use it for this puzzle, removing a lot of the mystery. I know they do that to keep you from being overwhelmed, but it's a dead giveaway. There was one puzzle that was timed and required a LOT of typing. I type about 60 wpm and comparable on a number pad, but the typing for that puzzle required switching between the two and using a keystroke (the vertical bar i.e. | ) I have rarely used and so had trouble finding it quick enough to solve the puzzle. I can't imagine anyone who can't 10 finger type solving that one. (Plus no copy/paste function! The horror!)
 
So, is this real hacking? Almost certainly not even close. Is it fun? Maybe not for programmers, but as a neophyte I definitely enjoyed it. It took me about 4 hours, but there was a LOT of idle time when I was looking stuff online or trying to figure out some programming puzzles on my own.  The story is not super involved and some of the commands get tedious, but if you find it on sale, this game is worth a buy.

7/10. Fun, but probably wouldn't replay it.

review:
[h1]About Mu Complex[/h1]
The game is a puzzle game. The whole gameplay is about reading through files and finding hints and solving puzzles.
Mu Complex is about 2 - 4 hours long, depending on your puzzle solving skills.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
This is quite subjective, but I would consider the difficulty medium. Some puzzles, like the bot puzzles, were rather challenging and even required me to look up help.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
The game runs very well on lower machines, so I wouldn't worry about that.
However, the game does not enjoy being switched to fullscreen mode (by using alt+enter), but you don't want that anyways.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
I'd consider the replayability rather low. After you finished the game, there isn't really a reason to replay it again.

[h1]Anything special?[/h1]
This is only a very minor spoiler, but if you are absolutely hardcore, don't read it: [spoiler]Several puzzles require you to do something outside the game[/spoiler], which I personally found extremely appealing.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game if you are into puzzle or adventure games.
The only downside is the rather short playtime, but the vast majority of it was well spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250694352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1090, 'last_played': 1470719190}
review:
As some are quick to point out, Mu Complex is not a 'hacking game'. There's no frenetic action, load balancing packet transfers across multiple servers or firewall cracker mini-games. Instead, you're an e-spy, learning just enough about your targets to steal their secrets, before moving on to the next-to-be-victimized terminal. So Mu's not a 'hacking game', it's actual hacking.

The puzzles grow fairly linearly in difficulty, beginning with laughable non-effort and culminating in multiple notebook pages of nightmarish chicken scratch. Like many adventure games of the internet age, Mu requires that you befriend Google, researching beyond the in-game assets. Accordingly, the developers have created a suite of real world, online content to further your immersion into the complex world of Complex.

Unfortunately, all of that outside browsing accompanies an odd, recurring bug. Alt-Tab'ing out blanks the game screen, seemingly erasing your progress. Resizing the game screen fixes the problem immediately, but I suffered through a bit of 'close-and-replay' before stumbling upon that solution.

Overall, using only minimal interface and unobtrusive music, Mu Complex creates an appropriately tense atmosphere as you dig through the sins of the past. The simulated voice acting is sometimes soothing and sometimes unnerving... So much so, in fact, that when I updated Windows 10 recently and the screen displayed HELLO in big block letters, I flinched... Play the game, you'll understand why...

It took me 6-7 hours to complete the two standard episodes, having read through every accessible message and taken the relevant notes. Beyond that, there is additional content that I will refrain from spoiling, so the total package well justifies the current $9 price point. For the fellow Achievement Hunters, it took me 21 hours for 100% completion, with one particular achievement requiring a lot of patience... you'll know it when you see it... so have a book handy.

Update: My nominee for The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award

review:
The description of a command line style hacking game was an automatic hook for me. I really like the hacking theme and have tried several types. 

Apparently this is based on linux style commands, but even with no experience I had no trouble navigating menus. There is tab completion for most of the commands and files for ease of use. The soundtrack basically consists of long tones followed by more long tones, so I recommend muting it. The game comes with two "episodes" to complete. My playtime for episode 1 was about an hour and four hours for episode 2. I enjoyed that you had to use outside tools to complete the puzzles. Don't be afraid to use screencaps, google, or software to help with the puzzles. The storyline is pretty straightforward, but if you dig a little deeper there are a few easter eggs. Looking through the achievements I definitely missed a few things so I will probably go back for them. 

Great game for less than $10.

review:
Тут много задач, требующих... гугления! В прямом смысле этого слова -_- Например, вам предлагается найти в архивах на сайте журнала определенный номер и посмотреть на рекламу на указанной странице. При всём при этом, какой-то особой интеллектуальной сложностью задачи не отличаются - это вам не TIS-100 и даже не Hacknet.

Однако есть и три жирных плюса. Игра очень добротно сделана. Падают дорогие карточки, почти полностью окупающие цену со скидкой в 99 рублей. И сюжет, начинающийся почему-то только со второго эпизода...

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197994259403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1456011739}
review:
I (probably a mistake) went in expecting a "hacking" game, in the wake of games such as Uplink or HackNET. This... is a completely different thing. It's more a series of stale, extremely simple puzzles or mini-games that you just have to complete to progress.
Mu complex also tries to use clever "real life" puzzles - which would be interesting if this genre hadn't existed for more than a decade (see Ouverture Facile for instance).

In addition the story is not only boring, it's also infuriating. You can see the twist coming from a mile away - hours before finishing the main game. Yes this means there is a post game. I didn't finish it. It started feeling like a grind. The thing is : cracking codes can be fun, but most of what Mu Complex asks of you is not to crack the code, it's to apply the formula. It's not enticing.

So what's left? There is no real music - just background atmospheric. It becomes agravating fairly quickly. The UI then? Yeah the UI is pretty good. It works, it looks slick and it's appropriate and functional. However the controls (typing really) are not. It feels very frustrating to have the commands available to you change on every single stage (computer), spelling out the answer for you. What made you feel clever in a game like HackNET was figuring out what to do with all these tools you accumulated. Nothing of that challenge here - we give you only what you need so that you're not lost.

I wanted to love that game, I really did. We don't get enough hacking games and these can be so fun. But a hacking game this is not. This is a series of mediocre puzzles, under a decent looking coat. There's definitely potential, but it's not there yet.

review:
Купил эту игру за 199р. Для кого это весомые деньги - не покупайте ее, лучше купите Скайрим за 99р. по новогодней акции. Но если у вас завалялись лишние деньги, то покупайте смело, вы их не выбросите на ветер хотябы из-за приятного оформления, что нехарактерно для игры такого жанра.

Для меня игра показалась очень легкой (самая трудная и интересная задачка становится доступна только по окончании основных эпизодов). Первый эпизод - ознакомительный и проходится примерно за час, второй более масштабный. Если вы можете в логику и самые азы программирования, то пройдете игру часов за 6-7 (опять же, для последней задачки время я в расчет не брал, потому что ее решение не обязательно).

Сами головоломки хоть и сводятся всегда к нахождению пароля, но разнообразны и креативны. В дальнейшем хочется разнообразия еще и в цели решения.

А вот что я никак не могу оправдать, так это сюжет. Он настолько неинтересен, затерт и предсказуем, что на него вообще можно не обращать внимания. Радует только наличие озвучки фраз нашей ИИ.

Надеюсь, что третий эпизод учтет ошибки второго, обзаведется интересным сюжетом и более сложными задачками. 
Поставлю Мю Комплексу 7 имэйлов из [strike]128[/strike] 10 и куплю-таки Сибирь, ибо лучше квеста нету.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986558934', 'num_games_owned': 7338, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1448195313}
review:
[i]Note : Ce jeu m'a été offert par son développeur, sans aucune attente ou compensation particulière. Cette recommendation est une iniative personnelle avec une liberté totale dans mes écrits et mon ressenti.[/i]


Si je devais vous positionner le genre de Mu Complex à l'aide d'une référence parlante pour tous, je serais bien embarassé... car Mu Complex fait partie de ces jeux au concept étonnant et unique ne pouvant trouver de rapprochement quelconque dans ses mécaniques avec un autre jeu vidéo existant. Ce qui a attisé encore plus ma curiosité par ailleurs.

Vous commencez le jeu avec une console de commande Linux, comportant le texte suivant :

[i]"Mu Complex is a Governmental Company.
You have to connect on your Mu account, please login to proceed."[/i]

Puis.... c'est tout. Vous êtes maintenant face à cette console de commande, seul, sans aucune aide supplémentaire. Vous devez donc mettre à profit les différentes commandes Linux (qui correspondent [u]réellement[/u] aux commandes du fameux système d'exploitation) pour vous sortir de ce premier obstacle. Votre réflexe est donc de taper "help" pour accéder aux commandes que vous pouvez utiliser, ainsi qu'à leur fonction.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=560300179

Pour ce premier défi (que vous pouvez plutôt considérer comme un tutoriel), vous constaterez que les commandes sont somme toute primaires. Après un rapide coup d'oeil aux commandes permises à ce stade, la solution se dégage d'elle-même.

Mais une fois cette première étape terminée, fini la rigolade, le jeu peut enfin commencer. L'assistant informatique vous fait savoir que vous ne vous êtes plus connecté depuis des dizaines d'années... bizarre pour une agence gouvernementale et de quoi éveiller notre curiosité et notre attention.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=560300234

Cette fois-ci, la solution ne semble plus si apparente et demande donc de tâtonner avec les commandes octroyées pour dégager un début de piste...

Je m'arrête là concernant les photos et l'avancement du jeu. Mon but n'étant pas de tout vous spoiler et de vous gâcher le fil directeur de l'histoire :) !

Parlons d'ailleurs de ce fameux fil directeur... au fur et à mesure de votre avancement, vous en apprendrez de plus en plus sur l'histoire mystérieuse de l'agence Mu Complex et de ses secrets à l'aide de multiples documents (mails, photos...). Il sera très difficile de décrocher ensuite de cette narration et vous serez sûrement tenter de terminer l'histoire d'une traite.

Les commandes, quant à elles, se diversifient et se complètent, ouvrant des possibilités plus larges et une difficulté grandissante, qui se ressentira à chaque niveau afin de vous offrir un challenge de plus en plus corsé et une satisfaction d'autant plus grande à chaque réussite, qui fera croitre en vous votre âme de hackeur.

Les défis évoluent eux-aussi et ne se ressemblent pas, vous demandant, par exemple, de prendre le contrôle d'autres ordinateurs se trouvant sur le réseau ou encore de pirater une caméra de sécurité, permettant de voir autre chose que cette unique console de commande austère.

Le jeu est séparé en 3 épisodes, dont deux sont déjà disponibles. Le troisième quant à lui, arrivera un peu plus tard sous une forme encore inconnue (DLC ? Mise à jour gratuite ?). L'épisode 1 vous prendra environ 01h30 à terminer et l'épisode 2, quant à lui, nécessitera plutôt 3-4h (tout dépend de vos difficultés face à certaines enigmes).


Non, décidément, j'ai beau chercher, je ne vois absolument pas de jeux comparables à Mu Complex, qui offre une expérience jusqu'ici unique, immersive et jouissive que je conseille très fortement.

I am a software engineer and a gamer, so this game immediately became a 'must buy' for me. Having played through the first two episodes (can't wait for the third),  I can say that this may be the best hacking game I have ever played.

The game really does make you feel like a hacker, as you're dropped onto a linux-like environment with a terminal and desktop. All while you have a really sweet electronic music playing as a part the games sound track. If you wanted to feel like Neo, this game is the one.

The puzzles are really sweet. Why? The game forces you to use "outside resources" to solve some of the puzzles - ie: using google maps, searching wikipedia to figure out musical notes, all to deconstruct a timed puzzle. Oh, and yes, the puzzles had me streaming all kinds of profanities at times - a good sigh the puzzles are well made.

Unlike other hacking games, this one is fully voiced. THANK YOU. 

The graphics are clean, minimalist and sharp. Exactly the right combo for this sort of game.

There is a 'good' story for what it is, and the cliff hangers after each episode have me yearning for more.

Buy this, even if you're only mildly interested in the subject of computers, or if you're just into puzzles. Even if you think the game might feel a bit to challenging, because each puzzle solved is rewarded with an amazing sense of joy.

review:
Шикарная головоломка, где вы будете взламывать свои, чужие компы, системы защиты и т.д.

Подробнее:

Сюжет: Личные данные главного героя мы узнаем где-то спустя полчаса игры, также нам известо то, что он работал на правительственную компанию... Последний запуск с пк гг был сделан около 60 лет назад, когда ему было 30 лет... Собственно, главный ли это герой или кто-то еще - неизвестно. Выходит, что играем мы за некоего человека, которому нужно получить доступ на самые высшие уровни секретности компании. За час игры больше ничего узнать не удалось! Сюжет интригует и это замечательно.

Геймплей: Игра представляет собой симулятор хакерства. Перед нами командная строка. Мы в праве вводить некоторые команды. Цель - найти пароль или кодовое слово и получить доступ на более высокий уровень. Для начала войди в свой комп как админ. Получилось? - Браво! Теперь войди в комп на 2 уровень доступа, используя файлы, разбросанные на твоем компе, а также на компах твоих коллег. В ход идет чтение писем, просмотр файлов, картинок и т.д. По геймплею игра похожа на еще 1 отличный квест-головоломку - Her Story.

Графика: В таких играх графика вообще не решает, однако разработчики сделали хорошее оформление, которое не вызывает нареканий. Действительно начинаешь верить, что засел за терминал мегакорпорации! 

Звук и музыка: фоновая музыка сойдет, но иногда включается странный такой шум - вот он вообще ни к чему (музыку можно отключить). 

Что мы имеем - отличный квест-головоломка про хакерство с интересным сюжетом и хорошим геймплеем. Игра обязательна к покупке тем, кто хочет поломать голову!

Если было мало обзора - вот видео:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H5DejGp-Cs0

В Mu Complex Вам предстоит при помощи команд терминала и Вашего браузера раскрыть тайны секретной компании и помочь некой Lya. Игра состоит из по-настоящему интересных и порой очень сложных головоломок. Для решения большинства из них вся необходимая информация находится в интернете, во время поиска которой Вы, возможно, узнаете много нового для себя. 

Игра бегло проходится за 4-5 часов, но в ней полно секретного контента, на поиск которого может потребоваться предположительно еще столько же времени.

Своих денег Mu Complex точно стоит, всем советую к покупке. Вот.

review:
取り敢えずエピソード1はクリア。テキストベースのアドベンチャーでハッキングらしいハッキングとはいえない。CTFのようなおもしろ課題とみるべきだろうか。
Linuxコマンドを使ってパズルと解いていくと説明にあったので買ってはみたものの、コマンドは最小限しかないし、コマンドを使う謎解きの内容はかなりあっさりしている。数々のヒントからパスワードを類推していく場面が多い印象。

lsコマンドにオプションを付ける必要はなく、誰のPCにもルートディレクトリにパスワードに関するヒントが書かれてるファイルが無造作においてあるので、セキュリティ意識低すぎだろと心のなかでツッコミを入れながら、繋がっている他のPCにログインして施設のシステム中枢に迫っていく。sudoコマンドの使い方も正直蛇足だったのでもう少しやりようがあったはず。面白く機能していたのはsshコマンドとEp2のミニゲームくらい。

後半からパスワードのヒントに[spoiler]古いシカゴトリビューン紙の見出しや聖書の引用を聞かれるが、わかるわけないのでネットで調べる必要がある。もっとも後になると文字コード/モールス信号のエンコード、TwitterアカウントやMu Complex用のサイトフォームから情報を拾ったりとしなければならず、[/spoiler]面白い試みだが少々面倒だしゲーム内で完結してない要素が多すぎるのも如何なものか。KongregateにあったEp1/Ep2はSteamリリースにあたり削除されたそうだが、値段つけてSteam版を売るならEp3かアフターエピソードみたいなものが欲しかった。こういうゲームが得意な人にとっては結構短めです。

author: {'steamid': '76561197974520973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1445732231}
review:
TL;DR: Great concept, lousy execution.

Before I begin, you should know I'm coming to this game from the perspective of an adept Linux user. The terminal is where I live. So when I read that we'd be using "actual Linux commands" to solve hacking puzzles, I wouldn't click buy fast enough. Unfortunately, "actual Linux commands" essentially meant ultra stripped-down versions of ls, cat, ssh and sometimes sudo.

The puzzles themselves were decently creative, but way too simple. About 90% of the puzzles could be solved with some variation on the form (1) read the emails for clues then (2) type in the password to unlock the username / password for the next computer . About half the puzzles require a simple Google search which seemed cool about twice before it got annoying. Overall, the puzzle aspect felt formulaic and underdeveloped.

Some nice work went into writing the emails between the office workers and I enjoyed getting to know the story through that device. Everything from the story/atmosphere perspective was VERY solid.

I think there's a ton of potential in this type of game, especially for teaching people about how to use Linux. It just needs more work to make people really have to work to solve the puzzles. Codesleuthing is tons of fun, but it just doesn't feel fair when your puzzle is as simple as translating morse code or maritime signal flags. Also, there's no reason this game shouldn't have had a better terminal emulator. More terminal options would have meant more complex and satisfying puzzles.

Overall, it's a fun diversion for a couple hours, but that's about it. It definitely isn't $9 of entertainment. I think this developer is definitely on the right track and I look forward to their next release, but this game can easily be skipped.

review:
Big Review Update:

General:
I love this game, the way you have to think way outside of the box to solve the puzzles is just amazing. I definitely want more games like this.
And to clarify this version of the game has the first and second episode of MuComplex that where previously on kongregate.
I do not know how a possible release of a third episode might be handled.

As much as I love the game, the way the steam release has been handled was pretty bad. The free version was shut down without much prior warning and for the way the port was done its a bit expensive.

About the Port:
It's basically still the same game as before. to my current knowledge only 2 things were added(hints that unlock after a certain time and some additional puzzle after beating both episodes) No gamechanging fetures were added. They even removed something substantial(ctrl+v) which made one of the puzzles difficult to solve.
Some features that could definitely not have hurt to add would be to make the terminal resizeable, allow you to open more than just one picture and let you resize and move those freely on the screen. Also there are no game options of any kind, you just get a small button to turn the complete audio on or off. It's pretty disappointing.


At last some praise:
*love the concept
*voice acting is kinda ok
*the end of episode 2 has a nice little cgi cutscene
*there are a lot of emails that are not necessary for puzzle solving, they add a nice atmosphere to the game and let you look into the workings of the mu complex

author: {'steamid': '76561197965467305', 'num_games_owned': 5877, 'num_reviews': 312, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1445841465}
review:
Pros and cons are probably the easiest way to help you make a decision on purchase MU Complex.

Pros:
Satisfying Linux command line based game play.
The puzzles are satisfying:
-Real world information puzzles that requires you to use Google.
-External MU Complex owned websites to solve puzzles are a nice touch.
The story is interesting.

Cons:
Having to retype commands many times over when stuck on a puzzle (A note pad can help relieve this)
I don't really like the sound track but it can be muted.
Everyone seems to save their passwords in a document called password.txt
While the "About the game" section leads you to believe you will become a "real hacker" I doubt this game will give you any real world hacker experience.
The console window does not support the mouse scroller

Overall the cons are fairly minor and don't take anything away from the experience and I consider the game put together well. I recommend this game to people the enjoy puzzle games and visual novel style games.

Constructive criticism:
I think there is a missed opportunity to support dual monitors.
